citations.desc: Primary enclosures used to transport live guinea pigs and hamsters.
citations.narrative:
A transport enclosure housing 5 Chinese hamsters (# 3116) did not provide adequate ventilation to ensure proper airflow
during transport. There was no ventilation on the sides of the enclosure. The top of the transport enclosures had 6 small
holes. Failure to provide adequate ventilation can affect the health and well-being of the animals. Primary transport
enclosures for hamsters must contain ventilation openings that are at least 16 percent of the total surface area if on two
walls or at least 8 percent of the total surface area if on four sides to ensure adequate airflow. Correct by May 5, 2025.

citations.desc: Primary enclosures used to transport live birds.
citations.narrative:
The transport enclosures for 13 finches (Tag # 3200, 3201, 3202, 3203, and 3204), did not provide adequate ventilation
openings to ensure proper airflow during transport and had accumulated condensation on the inside of the enclosures.
One enclosure, housing three finches (# 3204), had long sides of the transport enclosures with six ventilation openings
measuring 0.2 sq inches each with the total surface area of the long sides measuring approximately 32.5 sq inches. This
equated to 3.7% of the total surface area for ventilation on the long sides. The long sides would need a total of 5.2 sq
inches for the ventilation to be compliant (16% of each side).
Inadequate ventilation openings can decrease the airflow within the enclosure and impact the health of the birds during
transport.
Primary transport enclosures for birds must contain ventilation openings on at least two vertical sides with at least 16
percent of the total surface area if on two walls or at least 8 percent of the total surface area if on four walls.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
ROBERT MARKMANN, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

narrative:
3.36(a)(5) 
   
Primary enclosures used to transport live guinea pigs and hamsters. 
A transport enclosure housing 5 Chinese hamsters (# 3116) did not provide adequate ventilation to ensure proper airflow 
during transport. There was no ventilation on the sides of the enclosure. The top of the transport enclosures had 6 small 
holes. Failure to provide adequate ventilation can affect the health and well-being of the animals. Primary transport 
enclosures for hamsters must contain ventilation openings that are at least 16 percent of the total surface area if on two 
walls or at least 8 percent of the total surface area if on four sides to ensure adequate airflow. Correct by May 5, 2025. 
3.162(b)(1)  Repeat
   
Primary enclosures used to transport live birds. 
The transport enclosures for 13 finches (Tag # 3200, 3201, 3202, 3203, and 3204), did not provide adequate ventilation 
openings to ensure proper airflow during transport and had accumulated condensation on the inside of the enclosures. 
One enclosure, housing three finches (# 3204), had long sides of the transport enclosures with six ventilation openings 
measuring 0.2 sq inches each with the total surface area of the long sides measuring approximately 32.5 sq inches. This 
equated to 3.7% of the total surface area for ventilation on the long sides. The long sides would need a total of 5.2 sq 
inches for the ventilation to be compliant (16% of each side).  
Inadequate ventilation openings can decrease the airflow within the enclosure and impact the health of the birds during 
transport. 
Primary transport enclosures for birds must contain ventilation openings on at least two vertical sides with at least 16 
percent of the total surface area if on two walls or at least 8 percent of the total surface area if on four walls. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
ROBERT MARKMANN, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n
